courseDescription: This course will introduce students to action research, a form of self-reflective, systematic inquiry by educators of their own practice.  Students will learn about research methods, design, and implementation, and they will develop action research proposals based on a line of structured inquiry emanating from events occurring within their own classrooms.  Teachers will study student learning related to their own teaching, a process which allows them to learn about their own instructional practices and to continue monitoring improved student learning.  Conducting action research provides educators with an avenue to reflect on their own teaching practices with the aid of empirical data and engage in self-directed learning with the ultimate goal of improving student learning.  Must have completed 15 Graduate credit hours in reading coursework.
Technical and Digital Skills: Monitoring and analysis of student learning data
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing and implementing action research proposals
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading structured inquiry within the classroom

courseDescription: Surveys theories and historical trends leading up to present day literacy instruction. Participants will learn how to incorporate application of current research to the methods and philosophies of teaching reading and writing. An integrated language model suggests that reading, writing, and thinking be viewed as interrelated, critical processes for exploring and responding to the world. Offers students an opportunity to acquire foundational knowledge of materials, instructional strategies, and assessment tools that support literacy and engaging learners
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilization of appropriate literacy instruction materials
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interrelated understanding of reading, writing, and thinking processes
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Integration of reading, writing, and thinking for problem solving

courseTitle: Approaches to Teaching Literature and Writing K-12
courseDescription: Explores the theory and practice of teaching literature, including young adult and children's literature, and writing.  Considers some of the characteristics of writing processes, the role of the teacher in structuring and responding to student writing, the role of the teacher in literary text selection, the relationships between writing and literacy understanding, and the authentic assessment of K-12 students' reading, writing and learning.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of young adult and children's literature
Authentic assessment of student's reading, writing and learning
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating the relationships between writing and literacy understanding
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessing student's reading, writing and learning
Selection and analysis of literary texts for teaching
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Guiding students in the writing process

courseDescription: Provides an overview of the field of linguistics, the scientific study of language and word study, an approach to spelling instruction that relies on an understanding of English orthography that incorporates instruction in phonics, spelling and vocabulary.  Students will learn to recognize characteristics of readers and writers at different levels of development.  The course provides multiple opportunities for hands-on practice and application.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Teaching strategies for different levels of learners
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Recognition of characteristics of readers and writers at different levels
Adaptation of teaching methods based on learner understanding

courseDescription: Provides for the examination, evaluation, and use of multicultural library materials and resources for elementary and middle school children.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation and analysis of multicultural library materials
Problem-solving in relation to multicultural literacy

courseTitle: Culturally Responsive Literacy for All Learners
courseDescription: Explores curriculum, instructions, materials and issues related to teaching literacy and language to diverse learners regardless of their ethnic, cultural, linguistic, cognitive, religious, gender, backgrounds, etc.
Technical and Digital Skills: Adapting teaching methods for diverse learners
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and addressing literacy gaps in diverse learners
Adapting teaching strategies to cater to diverse learning needs

courseTitle: Issues and Trends in Literacy Education
courseDescription: This course provides an opportunity for students to explore the critical trends and issues being debated within the field of Literacy Education.  This course will provide students with an in-depth understanding of significant issues, trends, and practices in reading instruction at the K-12 level.  The course is designed to deal with questions and problems of the type facing teachers, supervisors, and administrators.  In addition to providing students with a deeper understanding of current trends and the latest literacy research, this course will also help students to critique ideas and issues surrounding informed instruction within literacy education.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and applying current literacy research
Implementing effective reading instruction strategies at K-12 level
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Debating and discussing issues in Literacy Education
Communicating educational strategies to other teachers, supervisors, and administrators
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critiquing ideas and issues in Literacy Education
Addressing and solving problems faced by teachers, supervisors, and administrators
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Keeping up with trends and issues in Literacy Education
Leading informed instruction within literacy education
Supervising reading instruction at K-12 level

courseDescription: This course focuses on the literacy coach's roles and responsibilities in conducting school-wide, needs-based assessments and planning professional development to align with assessments. Multiple perspectives and approaches to considering, piloting, and administering needs-based surveys and analyzing data for schools and school divisions are explored and practiced. Using results, data-based professional development planning is studied and practiced. Through interactive online instruction, lecture, projects, and reflective participation based upon the International Reading Association's Standards and The Virginia Standards of Learning, a professional knowledge base will be developed. This course provides experiences on a variety of levels to further the development of the literacy coach within ODU's Educator as Professional Framework.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analyzing data for schools and school divisions
Professional development planning based on data
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Approaches to surveys and data analysis
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning professional development aligned with assessments
Understanding and applying the International Reading Association's Standards and The Virginia Standards of Learning

courseTitle: New Literacies, Digital Technologies, and Learning
courseDescription: This course is designed to provide a context in which in-service teachers can explore a range of "new" literacies and consider their relationships to school-based literacy education.  Participants will explore these new literacies, specifically the socially immersive experiences of youth and their new media practices.  These participating educators will examine the role of multimodality in literacy learning across the curriculum with an emphasis on how to bridge the digital literacies of students' private lives with the traditional print practices valued in school.  Teachers will gain insight into and understanding of how young people's participation in a shifting media landscape can help shape and form learning and literacy in the 21st Century classroom.
Technical and Digital Skills: Adapting traditional print practices to digital literacies
Integration of digital literacies into curriculum
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Bridging private and educational digital practices
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding the role of shifting media landscape in learning
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Implementing new literacies into school-based literacy education
Integrating digital and traditional literacies in classroom

courseDescription: Presents an overview of current reading research and its application to instruction.  Provides study and practice in the use of quantitative or qualitative techniques, including analytical processes, in solving problems in reading education.

This class has an emphasis on advanced techniques in literacy for classroom teachers who are not reading specialists. Students will develop an understanding of literacy across the curriculum, including a wide variety of instructional strategies and an understanding of the complex nature of literacy within the disciplines. Lecture, demonstrations, development of materials/planning approaches, and practice in the techniques of literacy instruction for K-12 classroom teachers and library media specialists are provided.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Instructional strategies for K-12 classroom and library media specialists
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding of literacy across the curriculum
Analyzing the complex nature of literacy within the disciplines
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading literacy instruction for K-12 classroom teachers and library media specialists
Organizing and planning literacy instruction materials

courseTitle: Diagnostic Teaching of Reading in the Classroom
courseDescription: Provides classroom teachers with strategies/techniques to employ to ongoing diagnosis and remediation through the use of informal and standardized tests to select appropriate instructional strategies for pupils' existing reading capabilities.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of educational technology for remediation
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Adjusting communication based on pupil's reading capabilities
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing classroom based on diagnostic results

courseTitle: Organizing and Supervising Reading Program Development
courseDescription: Presents an overview of the total school reading program (K-12), and not only prepares the prospective reading supervisor to make decisions pertaining to the procurement of materials for the program but also explores modes for integrating reading into the general curriculum.
Technical and Digital Skills: Integration of reading into general curriculum
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Decision making for reading program development

courseDescription: Explores current theories of cognitive development and their relationship to language development and reading as bases for evaluating methods and materials of teaching reading and the related communicative arts: spelling, writing, and speaking.
Surveys the linguistic, psychological, sociological, philosophical, and historical foundations of current reading pedagogy.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of psychological theories in reading
Familiarity with sociological aspects of reading instruction
Understanding of historical contexts of reading pedagogy
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication of philosophical ideas in reading instruction
Ability to discuss psychological theories effectively
Interpretation of sociological factors in reading
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of linguistic structures in reading
Application of psychological theories to reading challenges
Evaluation of sociological influences on reading pedagogy
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Integration of various foundations in reading pedagogy
Organizing historical contexts for effective instruction
Leadership in philosophical discussions in reading instruction

courseDescription: Hours to be arranged.  This course provides graduate teachers with opportunities to practice and further refine their understandings of the reading process in clinical and classroom settings.  Teachers provide both individual and group reading lessons with students from the local community.  Advanced diagnostic tests of learning processes and intellectual capacity are covered.  These advanced diagnostic techniques are in addition to those covered in the initial diagnostic reading course.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interaction with students from the local community
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Management of clinical and classroom settings

courseDescription: This course is a pass/fail course for master's students in their final semester. It may be taken to fulfill the registration requirement necessary for graduation.  All master's students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour in the semester of their graduation.
